answers.explanation:
The fundus photographs demonstrate bilateral marked disc swelling in the right eye with subtle peripapillary hemorrhages and a disc at risk with mild diffuse pallor in the left eye. You can also appreciate focal yellow/white chorioretinal lesions in the juxtapapillary region OU (green arrows). These chorioretinal lesions are highlighted as stippled hyper-autofluorescence foci on FAF imaging (blue arrows).

![](/content/media/neuro_opht_28_5.webp)

![](/content/media/neuro_opht_28_6.webp)

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: What are the main findings seen in the fundus photo and fundus autofluorescence images above?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
Formal 24-2 Humphrey visual fields were conducted, which demonstrated dense generalized depression in the left eye and an inferior altitudinal defect in the right eye (shown below):

![](/content/media/neuro_opht_28_7.webp)

At this point, the patient was further questioned about his visual complaint. He did note visual decline over the last 6 months in the left eye. He was further probed on a review of systems, and he did disclose risky sexual behaviours including unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple male partners a week.

OCT ONH/RNFL and OCT macula images were taken at this time and are shown below:

![](/content/media/neuro_opht_28_8.webp)

![](/content/media/neuro_opht_28_9.webp)

![](/content/media/neuro_opht_28_10.webp)

What is the main finding in the OCT macula images above?

answers.answerText: B. Disruption of the ellipsoid zone
answers.explanation:
Both images demonstrate irregularities and discontinuity of the ellipsoid zone (blue arrows), which is the hyper-reflective band anterior to the RPE. The ellipsoid zone is formed by the mitochondria of the photoreceptors, and is crucial in maintaining visual function at the macula. The underlying RPE also demonstrates a granular appearance.

![](/content/media/neuro_opht_28_11.webp)

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Based on the patient presentation, fundus findings and OCT imaging, what is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.answerText: B. Multiple evanescent white dot syndrome

answers.explanation:
This patient presented with bilateral optic neuropathy, specifically a pale left optic disc and disc swelling in the right eye confirmed on OCT RNFL imaging. He also had a left outer retinopathy with placoid chorioretinitis appearance in the left macula more so than the right on OCT macula imaging. Finally, he had scattered faint white dots in the retina, highlighted by fundus autofluorescence. These findings in a sexually active man increases the pre-test probability of syphilitic placoid chorioretinopathy.

Ocular syphilis is known as the great mimicker of ocular disease. Acute syphilitic placoid chorioretinopathy typically presents with a ground-glass pattern of multifocal or confluent chorioretinal lesions within in the peripapillary region. The hallmark findings are hyper-autofluorescence of the lesions, as well as disrupted ellipsoid zone with granularity of the underlying RPE on OCT macula imaging.

​References:

​Eandi CM, Neri P, Adelman RA, Yannuzzi LA, Cunningham ET. Acute syphilitic posterior placoid chorioretinitis: report of a case series and comprehensive review of the literature. Retina. 2012;32(9):1915–1941.

Pichi F, Ciardella AP, Cunningham ET, et al. Spectral domain optical coherence tomography findings in patients with acute syphilitic posterior placoid chorioretinopathy. Retina. 2014;34(2):373–384.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text:
The patient underwent syphilis serology screening. He was reactive for syphilis serology, with a RPR quant level of 1:1024.

What is the treatment of acute syphilitic placoid chorioretinitis?

answers.explanation: Ocular syphilis is classified as a tertiary syphilitic infection, which requires consultation of infectious diseases and treatment with IV penicillin for 10-14 days. The patient should also have screening for other associated sexually transmitted diseases. Ocular syphilis is a reportable public health infection; therefore, your local health advisory should be notified based on your location.

title: Case 28
description: 54M presenting with optic nerve swelling OD
patientPresentation:
A 54-year-old man presented to a neuro-ophthalmology clinic following a referral for optic nerve swelling. The patient’s only initial symptoms was 2-3 weeks of colourful flickering lights on his left visual field, which was worse in the mornings than evenings. He initially denied vision loss, eye pain, headaches or meningeal symptoms. He denied recent trauma or infection. He denied drug use or risky sexual behaviour. His last eye exam was 6 months prior to presentation, and his vision and eye exam were normal. His past medical history was significant for T2DM and hypertension, of which he was appropriately treated with medications.

On examination, his best corrected distance visual acuity was 20/40 OD and 20/200 OS. Intraocular pressure was normal and there was no RAPD. Anterior segment examination was normal. Fundus photos and fundus autofluorescence images were taken and are shown below:

### Learning Objectives:

1. Learn the hallmark OCT features of acute syphilitic placoid chorioretinitis. 

2. Understand that ocular syphilis can mimic a number of ocular infectious and inflammatory conditions, and targeted questioning of risky behaviours should be undertaken.
